Tactic.Content: Buffer management mechanism is regularly and continuously used to identify the resources that belong to groups 1,2 and 3.

NecessaryAssumptions.Content: Not knowing the ratio between the recruitment cycle time and the time-to-need (the time between the project start date and the time the resources is supposed to start participating in the project) leads to either recruiting too early, or worst too late.

Strategy.Content: The company recruits the required resources ensuring adequate availability for its projects.

ParallelAssumptions.Content:
Using the scheduling SW (considering projects already in execution and expected projects) it is possible to evaluate the load on the resources that belong to groups 1,2 and 3 and the expected time the company will run out of sufficient capacity with these resources - their respective time-to-need (TTN).

It is possible to start recruiting resources, that belong to groups 1, 2 and 3 that have recruitment cycle which is shorter then their TTN so that their recruitment ends (just) before they are required.

For resources that belong to groups 1, 2 and 3 that have recruitment cycle which is (much) longer then their respective TTN, experience shows that increasing capacity immediately by 20% creates sufficient capacity buffer..

Tactic.Content: The company categorizes the resources required according to the ratio between their TTN and their recruitment cycle and for those that the ratio is (much) higher then 1 recruits them so they are ready just before they are required. For resources with ration (much) above 1, immediately increase their capacity by 20% (build a capacity buffer).

NecessaryAssumptions.Content:
• To rapidly achieve the VV it behooves the Company to have the ability to win significant bonuses on many projects.

  • For many projects (and more so, for sub-projects) there is almost no gain in early delivery. STILL, for almost every environment there are large categories of projects (less so for sub-projects) in which early delivery brings substantial gains (sometimes the gains of early delivery dwarf the price of the project).

Strategy.Content: On a considerable portion of the projects bonuses are gained.

ParallelAssumptions.Content:
• The company can bring down its lead time to be much shorter than market lead-times.

  • The sales force can learn to identify the right opportunities.

Tactic.Content: The Company builds the capabilities to: Effectively identify projects in which early completion has high value; Close bonus-based contracts; Deliver them successfully.

SufficiencyAssumptions.Content: When the one that has the pressing need is aware of the one that is able to fulfill it, a sale is likely to occur.

NecessaryAssumptions.Content: In many (most) projects, early completion does not have a real value for the project owner.

Strategy.Content: The company concentrates on doing business in categories where early completion is of a high value to the project owner.

ParallelAssumptions.Content: When the sales force is focused on the connection between project completion and value, the experience needed to identify the value-categories is rapidly built.

Tactic.Content: Prudent efforts (in market intelligence, sales and operational capabilities) are made to gradually shift the main business to categories where early completion is of a high value to the project owner.

SufficiencyAssumptions.Content: To ensure that a complicated, large task can be performed on “mass production” scale, art should be turned into robust processes.

NecessaryAssumptions.Content: For many projects (and more so, for sub-projects) there is almost no gain in early delivery. STILL, for almost every environment there are large categories of projects (less so for sub-projects) in which early delivery brings substantial gains (sometimes the gains of early delivery dwarf the price of the project).

Strategy.Content: The Company knows which markets to grow with the Early Completion offer.

ParallelAssumptions.Content:
The experience of selling the reliability offer provides the opportunity for the Company’s professionals to identify when there is also high value for early completion.

In many cases, the projects where early completion has high value are representative of a group of projects (projects category).

Tactic.Content:
During the implementation of the first phase (selling the reliability offer), the Company’s professionals examine each opportunity to check (without giving the offer!) the value of early completion.

The parameters impacting the value and the projects categories where early completion is of high value are defined (this should be verified by approaching prospects implementing projects of the same category).

NecessaryAssumptions.Content:
When the details of an offer are not clearly laid out, it is easy to turn even the best sales offer into a mess.

When the details of the offer are not constructed to ensure benefits and mitigate risks (to both clients and the Company) the outcome may be losing many good sales opportunities and/or losing profit margins.

Strategy.Content: The Company has a detailed, early-completion offer that guarantees exceptional benefits to its clients while ensuring that the Company is not taking any real risk.

ParallelAssumptions.Content:
To construct a good offer four elements must be thoroughly understood:

  • The net benefit for the client relative to a standard offer.

  • The benefits to the Company.

  • The risk for the client (relative to the risk the client takes in a standard offer).

  • The risk to the Company (relative to the existing risk the Company

experiences in a standard offer).

Ensuring the benefits provides the detailed backbone of the offer. Mitigating the above risks provides important details of the offer.

Tactic.Content: A team is empowered to construct the details of the early completion offer (bonuses per time interval of early completion, and Terms & Conditions), maximizing the benefits (to both the clients and the Company) and minimizing the risks (to both the clients and the Company).

NecessaryAssumptions.Content:
• Asking for bonuses is a dramatic change for salespeople who argue on a daily basis with clients about price.

  • Operating without a competitive edge drives a company to try and win any opportunity coming their way. Having a decisive competitive edge behooves being selective in choosing opportunities. Making the shift to being selective is surprisingly difficult for most salespeople

Strategy.Content: Salespeople know how to present the early completion service option and reject inappropriate deals.

ParallelAssumptions.Content: Successful experience with an “unrealistic” offer, turns it into an “of course” offer.

Tactic.Content:
Train, coach, and handhold the salespeople (internal and external) in presenting the early completion service

The Company sales managers are coached not to compromise the offer’s key parameters when occasionally confronted with sales (or clients) pressures.

NecessaryAssumptions.Content: In projects where 1 month early completion brings value, usually, 2 months brings twice the value if not more.

Strategy.Content: The company relentlessly reduces project lead times.

ParallelAssumptions.Content: • Usually implementation of CCPM cuts the project lead time to about 3/4. When local improvements are constantly guided by CCPM, lead time can be reduced to be surprisingly short.

Tactic.Content:
The tactics detailed in 4.15.1 (POOGI) are constantly followed

(the cause for delays are always reported, the software is used to generate the Pareto analysis, and suitable improvement programs are set).
